He spoke for 18 minutes and managed to avoid asking — let alone answering — any essential questions about the war such as: Did it make America safer, and was it really worth it? And while Obama made that case when he spoke about the war in Afghanistan — “We will disrupt, dismantle, and defeat Al Qaeda, while preventing Afghanistan from again serving as a base for terrorists” — he did not make that case for Iraq. Because he could not. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Iraq war started over an appalling mistake or an outrageous lie: that there were weapons of mass destruction in Iraq and that a madman, Saddam Hussein, was sitting in his palace with his finger on the nuclear button. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR As we all now know, there were no such weapons. And in that sense, the war, which was launched by President George W. Bush, began as a fraud. But the price we paid was very real: Almost 7½ years of combat, more than 4,400 Americans dead, more than 35,000 wounded and more than $700 billion spent by U.S. taxpayers.
